clinical_study.brief_title: Compare Effects of Intensive Versus Conventional Lipid-lowering Therapy in Patients With Severe Atherosclerotic Renal Artery Stenosis Undergoing Stent Placement
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Randomized Trial to Compare Effects of Intensive Versus Conventional Lipid-lowering Therapy in Patients With Severe Atherosclerotic Renal Artery Stenosis Undergoing Stent Placement

lead_sponsor.agency: Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences, Fuwai Hospital

clinical_study.source: Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences, Fuwai Hospital

brief_summary.textblock: Although expert consensuses recommend the use of statins in the treatment of atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis, in patients with severe atherosclerotic renal artery stenosis undergoing stent placement, the related investigation focused on renal protection by intensive lipid-lowering therapy is scant , and the optimal target level for lipid reduction remain uncertain. Therefore, we hypothesized that intensive lipid lowering could offer more benefits with respect to renal function in the patients with percutaneous renal artery stenting. We conducted the prospective randomized unblinded trial to compare the renal-protective effect of intensive lipid lowering with that of conventional lipid lowering in patients underwent renal artery stenting (75 patients in each study group)

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Intensive lipid lowering gourp:10 mg/d rosuvastatin was initially prescribed and target LDL-C was < 1.8mmol/L; Conventional lipid lowering: 5 mg/d rosuvastatin was initially prescribed and target LDL-C was ≥1.8mmol/L, <3.3mmol/L

primary_outcome.measure: Change in estimated glomerular filtration rate

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in the number of antihypertensive medications

secondary_outcome.description: death from cardiovascular or renal causes, myocardial infarction, hospitalization for congestive heart failure, stroke, and a relative increase in SCr from baseline of ≥50%

arm_group.description: 10 mg/d rosuvastatin was initially prescribed and target LDL-C was < 1.8mmol/L
5 mg/d rosuvastatin was initially prescribed and target LDL-C was ≥1.8mmol/L, <3.3mmol/L

intervention.description: For patients who were assigned to receive intensive lipid lowering, 10 mg/d rosuvastatin was initially prescribed and target LDL-C was < 1.8mmol/L. For patients who were assigned to receive conventional lipid lowering, 5 mg/d rosuvastatin was initially prescribed and target LDL-C was ≥1.8mmol/L, <3.3mmol/L.
